Keywords: oceanography, marine geology, paleoclimate, geochemistry, micropaleontology, carbon cycle, ocean acidification
Outreach: public talks (e.g., Maine Upward Bound), providing STEM training for undergraduates and graduate students
Research: I investigate changes in Earth's climate and ocean chemistry, both past and present. Studying past ocean conditions helps us understand how the ocean-climate system operates on timescales that extend beyond historical records. Ancient marine sediments serve as a rich archive of the conditions in which they were deposited -- they contain chemical, physical, and biological signatures of ocean history. My group specializes in reconstruction of past ocean properties such as temperature and pH through geochemical analysis of microfossils preserved in seafloor sediments.
Teaching: ERS 316 Sedimentology & Stratigraphy, ERS 321/602 Paleoceanography, ERS 460/560 Marine Geology, ERS 201 Global Environmental Change.

Keywords: Ocean carbon cycle, primary production, El Nino, decadal variability, role of iron, global warming, marine ecosystems, Gulf of Maine, Peru, Arabian Sea, Pacific
Research: I study how physical and biological processes contribute to the carbon cycle, and how the biological pump transfers carbon into the deep ocean. My current research interests include: developing and testing physical-biological models in several regions, the equatorial Pacific and the coast of Peru, the Gulf of Maine, and the Arabian Sea; studying the nutrient transport from the interior ocean to the surface by the ocean circulation and mixing processes; assimilating satellite information into the physical-biological models, such as sea surfac e temperature and surface ocean color. Much of my work has been interdisciplinary, emphasizing physical and biological oceanography. I am also interested in using the stateof-the-art supercomputing power for the large scale ecosystem models.

Keywords: glaciers, ice sheets, glacier change, Arctic, Greenland, Antarctic, remote sensing, GPS
Outreach: I have served or I am currently serving as a committee/council member for a number of polar organizations, including the Association of Polar Early Career Scientists (APECS), International Glaciological Society, and International Arctic Science Committee Network on Arctic Glaciology. I have been the co-chair of the US National Committee for APECS since 2015 and have organized a number of online and in-person events for early-career polar scientists. I am also actively involved in outreach with secondary school students: I have given presentations on a wide range of topics to a number of local schools, judged 8th-grade science fair projects, and advised students participating in the Bangor High School STEM Academy.
Research: I study the impacts of climate change on the Earth's glaciers, ice caps, and ice sheets. My work primarily uses satellite and airborne (remotely-sensed) observations of glacier elevation, flow speed, and extent to better understand the variable behavior of the fast-flowing glaciers that drain the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets.
Teaching: Although I do not regularly teach courses, I taught a special section of ERS602 in Spring 2015 that focused on the physics of glaciers. I am also interested in teaching an Honors College tutorial on interactions between the cryosphere (i.e., the frozen parts of the planet) and climate that will be offered to junior-level undergraduates.

Research: Isotope measurements are the cornerstone in reconstructing past climate changes both in atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, past temperature fluctuations, seasonality, chronology, and water vapor provenance which can be interpreted in changes in large scale atmospheric circulation, sea ice concentration and any number of other climate variables. We measure the isotopic composition of snow, ice and carbonate materials to study past climate change and to interpret these large scale atmospheric changes.

Keywords: sustainable rates of organismal evolution, adaptations of organsims to human disturbances including climate change, conservation genetics in changing landscapes, conservation of fishes, amphibians and other taxa at the northern and southern extents of their species range
Research: I am an evolutionary biologist who focuses on recent and ongoing evolution of wild populations in response to human disturbances, including climate change, species invasions, harvest and other processes.  I am particularly interested in ways in which such evolution can influence the persistence of populations or contribute to structuring of associated communities and ecosystems through dynamic feedbacks.  Much of this work takes place in the context of conservation biology and natural resource management, but sometimes also considers evolutionary challnges tied to agriculture and human health.  In addition to some model fish species used to study these questions, my lab also studies these questions within the context of regionally important fish and amphibian populations that are likely to be particularly affected by climate change due to their location at the southern or northern extent of their species ranges.
Association: College of Natural Sciences, Forestry and Agriculture,Maine Agricultural and Forest Experiment Station

Keywords: lakes, ponds, lake ecology, climate impact
Research: I study the effects of cross-ecosystem interactions, such as materials and organisms that move across ecosystem boundaries. Climate change interacts with local human impacts to change the connections between these ecosystems. For instance, northern migration of pest species is causing a change in forest composition. This change in forest composition not only affects terrestrial ecosystems, but also alter aquatic ecosystems in those forests.

Research: I have two major research fields, both touching on climate change to a degree. HTY 241, History of Globalization: discussion of recent international relations and security problems includes climate change. Keywords: mammalian thermoregulation, evolutionary physiology, torpor, heterothermy, energetics, predicting species vulnerability to climate change
Research: My lab studies the comparative energetics and the evolution of mammalian temperature regulation. Through field and laboratory based experiments, we seek to understand how rigidity or flexibility in metabolism and body temperature regulation affects the energetics of a species, and how their evolutionary history has shaped these patterns. By understanding the dynamics of the relationship between an animal and its thermal environment, we can better predict energy budgets and responses to changes in climate and resource availability.
Teaching: BIO200 Biology of Organisms, BIO 433 Mammalogy, BIO 597 Species Topics: One Health and the Environment

Keywords: climate prediction, climate variability, human impacts, human and ecosystem response, chemistry of the atmosphere, Arctic, Antarctic, polar, ice core, glacier, Greenland
Outreach: Extensive public outreach through various media appearances, examples follow: CBS 60 Minutes Arctic Warning (2006) and The Age of Warming (2007), PBS, NOVA, NPR, Fox, BBC, Thin Ice (Winner Baikal International Film Festival and others), Years of Living Dangerously (Winner 2014 Emmy). Development, oversight and hands-on involvement in a variety of outreach activities (media, websites, workshops, displays, pamphlets, posters) for grade schools and high schools, civic groups, Museum of Science (Boston), American Museum of Natural History (New York); popular books (Mayewski and White, 2002, The Ice Chronicles; Mayewski and Morrison, 2010, Journey Into Climate).
Research: Documented changes in atmospheric chemistry produced naturally and by humans. Made early discovery of recent Antarctic and Himalayan ice loss. Discovered behavior of abrupt climate change events in the atmosphere. Developed integrated understanding of multiple controls on climate and the unique role of human impact on climate. Pioneered the use of instrumentally calibrated ice core records resulting in global reconstruction of past atmospheric circulation conditions. Made early demonstration of associations between past climate and disruptions to civilization. More than 375 peer-reviewed publications resulted from the above research. Developed innovative methods for the interpretation of glaciochemical series including: software for calibration between instrumental and ice core series for a variety of environmental phenomena such as sea ice extent, ENSO, NAO, AAO; plus unique analytical (LA-ICP-SFMS) and statistical methods. Organized and/or led several major scientific organizations including GISP2 (Greenland Ice Sheet Project 2 - 25 American institutions); ITASE (International Trans Antarctic Scientific Expedition - 21 nations); AICA (Asian Ice Core Array - 3 nations); Founding Director Climate Change Research Center (University of New Hampshire), PTC (Polar Tropical Connections - 10 nations); AIRMAP (Atmospheric Investigation Regional Mapping and Prediction - multi-disciplinary). Leader of more than 55 expeditions to Antarctica, the Arctic, Himalayas, Tibetan Plateau, Tierra del Fuego, Southern Ocean, and the Andes. Leader first expedition into Northern Victoria Land, Antarctica and first    glaciological expedition to Nun Kun Massif, Ladakh, Indian Himalayas. Leader of the first multi-disciplinary oversnow scientific expeditions to the South Pole through West and East Antarctica. Many Transantarctic Mountain first ascents and over 25,000 km of surface traverse over unexplored Antarctic territory.
Teaching: ERS 542 Introduction to Oceans, Atmosphere, Cryosphere and Past Climate (100%), ERS 602 Cliamte Analysis (100%), BUA 645 (ERS 602) Abrupt Cliamte Change, Business and Policy (1005)
Association: College of Natural Sciences, Forestry and Agriculture,Research Center or Institute

Keywords: nutrient cycles, nitrogen, denitrification, controls of primary production
Research: I study microbial controls of the global nitrogen cycle in marine ecosystems. I am interested in discovering new pathways in the nitrogen cycle and how this may impact understanding of controls. I am interested in exploring controls on pathways that compete for the same resources of nitrogen in the form of nitrate. My research is motivated by understanding controls on nitrogen availability and how this influences primary production. Additionally, the greenhouse gas nitrous oxide is produced and consumed by microbial processes, having direct impact on the radiative forcing of the atmosphere.
Teaching: SMS 491 - Microbes in the Environment. 25% deals with climate change.
Association: College of Natural Sciences, Forestry and Agriculture
